div1.head: Speech: Not by Bread Alone, by Philip Showalter Hench, January 1952
div1.p:
“NOT BY BREAD ALONE - - -”
Remarks by
Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn.

Mrs. Hench and I always enjoy coming back to Cuba to see the many friends who
have been so kind to us. Some of you may know that for fifteen years I have made
a study of the conquest of yellow fever, the fundamentals of which were developed
by Cuba's Dr. Carlos Finleay, one of the world's greatest benefactors. One of my
pleasant assignments on this trip is to present the official request of Surgeon
General Armstrong for copies of certain documents about Dr. Finleay for the Surgeon
General's library in Washington.

A year ago when I left Havana after the impressive and colorful dedication of
“Campamento Lazear” I took a set of Cuban stamps to my ten year old son John and this
pleased him very much. A few days ago, knowing that I was coming here again he brought
me his album to show me his collection of Cuban stamps. Of course he wanted me to see
not the ones he had but the ones he didn't have and I expect to take the hint!

One of the fascinations of postage stamps is that they reveal so much of the
history, culture and aspirations of each nation. Your stamps have appropriately
honored the memory of those who established “Cuba Libre” - such distinguished military
and political heroes as Maceo, Maximo Gomez, Jose Marti, Ignacio Agramonte, Calixto
Garcia, Carlos Manuel de Cespedes and others.

The postage stamps of Cuba also reflect your very real and progressive interest
in medical science and public health. Disseminated throughout the world have been
your colorful stamps honoring Carlos Finleay Nicolas Gutierrez, the Curies, our own
Clara Maass who died here and whom you have so graciously remembered, and others.
Additional stamps bear witness to your war against disease and disability, and
especially to your concern for the health of mothers and children.

Your sanitarians and physicians have rightly earned your respect and support
for they have made Cuba one of the healthiest as well as one of the loveliest spots
on earth. On each visit I have been impressed by the continuing development of new
hospitals, clinics and public health units.

These activities reveal your faith in two complementary concepts: 1. to be
healthy a nation must be “happy”, and conversely 2. to be happy a nation must be
healthy. But unfortunately it is no easy task for the sociologist and social
legislator to define and provide “national happiness”, nor can national health be
insured except through the earnest, ever-continuing efforts of many cooperating
agencies and people.

Now, I am informed, you are to make a new advance of considerable importance to
public health - namely the enrichment of flour. For some years this same problem has
engaged the attention of experts in my country, one of whom has been my teacher and
long-time colleague on the staff of the Mayo Clinic - Dr. Russell Wilder.

One may say: “But food is plentiful in Cuba and in the United States. Surely
we can eat enough bread and other food to keep us healthy. Why should we think of
enriching flour? What's wrong with ordinary flour and bread? If I miss anything
in ordinary bread surely I get it with the rest of my food!”

That was the belief of our forebears. But, because of certain scientific
developments, we now know that optinaloptimal nutrition cannot necessarily be guaranteed
for the individual who eats solely according to his personal food preferences.

Through the exercise of his intelligence man has learned through the centuries
how to modify his environment to meet his needs. By the use of suitable clothing,
shelter and various mechanical devices he regulates his temperature, and of late
even his atmosphere, so that he can live with reasonable comfort in the artics or
in the tropics, in the low deserts or high on the mountains and can fly far above
the highest peaks. Thus, too, he has developed a large measure of protection against
his enemies of the animal and bacterial kingdoms.

To insure adequate food and drink man has domesticated animals and fowls, built
reservoirs and aqueducts and developed agriculture so successfully that, in the United
States at least, the labor of one man is sufficient to feed fourteen others.

Till recent times man was concerned more about the quantity than the quality
of his food: his primary aim was to get enough food to satisfy hunger. Whatever
- 3 -
food choices he made were based on taste and sight, i.e. he selected what looked or
tasted good. We now know that such food habits commonly provided diets devoid or
deficient in certain essentials necessary for life or at least for the best of health.
Hence many of our ancestors were not as healthy or as long-lived as they should have
been. Theirs was still an era when only the fittest survived.

Then our grandparentsthe chemists, learning the early fundamentals of food chemistry, discovered
that there was more to proper eating than the mere gratification of taste or gratifica-
tion of hunger - to maintain health one must have a certain ratio of proteins, carbo-
hudrates and fats.

But along with his growing knowledge of food requirements our grandparentswe have
developed more and more food preferences, and also made important changes in the
preparation of food. Meats were processed by high temperatures; certain meats and
many vegetables were canned. These processes led to greater purity and long preserva-
tion of food. Our forebears turned from coarse flour and rough, brown bread to refined
flour and white bread. Developing a progressive liking for sugar they came to desire
and eat less protein.of other foods.

Meanwhile the science of nutrition was advancing rapidly. One's daily diet, if
regarded simply in terms of calories of protein, carbohydrates and fats became in-
adequate and outmoded. Instead, a “proper diet” was one which would supply at regular
intervals at least 30 or more specific nutrients: at least 8 essential protein-fractions
called amino acids, several vitamins, and the mineral salts of sodium, potassium, calcium,
iron, etc. Many of these are essential to life, and cannot be produced in the body, and
must therefore be present in our daily ration of food.

Armed with this knowledge nutritionists began, about 15 years ago, to view the
more sophisticated food habits of the American public with growing concern.

They found that the processing of meats by high temperatures often lowered their
nutritional value. Although the canning and processing of vegetables has been of
great practical value, some vitamins and amino acids are hurt thereby. Of particular
concern was the effect of refinement on bread, the staff of life. The flour used by
- 4 -
our grandmothers for baking bread was ground between stones, whereas ours is ground
between steel rolls. To cater to the public's marked preference for refined flour and
white bread American millers subject the whole wheat to 36 manipulations so as to
separate as completely as possible the endosperm or white flour from the wheat germ
and bran shorts. According to my colleague, Dr. Wilder, such processing reduces
100 pounds of whole wheat to 30 pounds of “feed” for cattle and 70 pounds of refined
flour. The latter is whiter but its vitamin content is markedly reduced.

This patent milling process (according to Dr. Sebrell of the U. S. Public Health
Service, one of America's outstanding experts on nutrition) deprives natural flour
of 90% of its thiamine (vitamin B1) and from 70% to 85% of its niacin (nicotinic acid),
riboflavin (vitamin B2) and iron. As a result, the 70 pounds of refined flour used by
man are much less nutritious than the residual 30 pounds of “feed” given to animals.
The part discarded by us contains practically all of the thiamine and most of several
other vitamins originally in the whole wheat. Hence in this respect animals are better
fed than man.

Although the refinement of flour provided a potential source of vitamin deficiency,
in view of the use of other foods was there an actual nutritional deficiency in our
“land of plenty”? Careful surveys of various experts uncovered many signs of such
deficiency. Surveys of food consumption showed (1939) that the diets of many Americans
were deficient in thiamine, niacin, riboflavin and iron. Pellagra, caused by a
deficiency of niacin and possibly also of riboflavin, was prevalent in various regions
and caused a significant number of deaths. Furthermore many persons were found to
suffer from (otherwise) unexplained lack of vigor and “ill health” - conditions which
have been produced experimentally in human volunteers given food low in thiamine.
Also a paradox was uncovered: certain persons could be obese and yet present evidence
of specific nutritional deficiencies.
